abstract: Apple holds its annual Macworld Expo and it’s chock-full of new high-tech goodies to be tried out.
snippet: Apple holds its annual Macworld Expo and it’s chock-full of new high-tech goodies to be tried out.
lead_paragraph: It’s a rock concert! It’s a pep rally! It’s a news conference!

headline.main: Gizmos, Gadgets and Steve Jobs, Too

abstract: If a friend’s digital music collection leaves you with playlist envy, instant gratification is one step closer.
snippet: If a friend’s digital music collection leaves you with playlist envy, instant gratification is one step closer.
lead_paragraph: If a friend’s digital music collection leaves you with playlist envy, instant gratification is one step closer. MiShare lets music connoisseurs swap files between iPods on the fly.

headline.main: With This Bridge Device, Songs Can March Directly From One iPod to Another
headline.print_headline: With This Bridge Device, Songs Can March Directly From One iPod to Another

abstract: Every time I put a blank CD into my Mac, iTunes pops up, even if I just want to burn photos to the disc. How can I burn the pictures?
snippet: Every time I put a blank CD into my Mac, iTunes pops up, even if I just want to burn photos to the disc. How can I burn the pictures?
lead_paragraph: Q. Every time I put a blank CD into my Mac, iTunes pops up, even if I just want to burn photos to the disc. How can I burn the pictures?

headline.main: Making iTunes Behave on a Mac

abstract: A lot of buzz still surrounds Apple chief Steve Jobs and his keynote address, with David Pogue and CNBC's Melissa Francis.
snippet: A lot of buzz still surrounds Apple chief Steve Jobs and his keynote address, with David Pogue and CNBC's Melissa Francis.
lead_paragraph: A lot of buzz still surrounds Apple chief Steve Jobs and his keynote address, with David Pogue and CNBC's Melissa Francis.

abstract: David Pogue invites you to grab your piano and sing along.
snippet: David Pogue invites you to grab your piano and sing along.
lead_paragraph: As long-time “From the Desk...” readers are no doubt aware, I spent the first ten years out of college working on Broadway as an arranger and conductor, killing time while trying to make my way as a composer/lyricist. Those days are long gone now, but from time to time, I still scratch my songwriting itch by writing new words to old melodies.

headline.main: Imagine a World Without Apple, Bloggers, Google or Dell
headline.kicker: From the Desk of David Pogue

abstract: The latest iPods have built-in clocks that could support music subscription services as well as movie rentals. The music industry still believes that their best option is to charge people a flat monthly rate for all they want to listen to. Apple, so far, disagrees.
snippet: The latest iPods have built-in clocks that could support music subscription services as well as movie rentals. The music industry still believes that their best option is to charge people a flat monthly rate for all they want to listen to. Apple, ...
lead_paragraph: One quick last word on Macworld and what Steve Jobs didn’t do. The technology that enables movie rentals also could enable music rentals — or, in other words, a music subscription service like Rhapsody.

headline.main: Where Is Apple’s Rental Service for Music?

abstract: Time Warner Cable plans to test a new price plan that would limit how much customers can download. Those who go over the limits might end up paying $4 to $30 to watch a high-definition movie.
snippet: Time Warner Cable plans to test a new price plan that would limit how much customers can download. Those who go over the limits might end up paying $4 to $30 to watch a high-definition movie.
lead_paragraph: Let’s say you buy a new Apple TV because you want to rent high-definition movies. And say you are about to move to Beaumont, Tex. If so, you might wind up paying Time Warner Cable as much as $30 when you download a movie using its high-speed Internet service.

headline.main: Time Warner: Download Too Much and You Might Pay $30 a Movie
